item.title: Distortion in Vertigo (1958)
item.description:
Alfred Hitchcock’s golden decade began in 1954 with Dial M for Murder, and ended with The Birds in 1963. The intervening years saw the Brit direct almost all of the films for which he is so well remembered today, including Rear Window, To Catch a Thief, North by Northwest, and Psycho. 1958’s Vertigo, however, has long been considered the absolute maximum of Hitchcock’s directorial function. I subjected myself to the movie at least three different times to understand its value among critics, but it is a seriously difficult film to approach: the film splits into two parts with the death of James Stewart’s love interest (Kim Novak), a woman whose doppelgänger (also portrayed by Novak) shows her face in the second half; the casting of James Stewart—with lead roles in It’s a Wonderful Life and Mr. Smith Goes to Washington—in lieu of transatlantic Hitchcock favorite Cary Grant, reads as an intentional subversion of 1950s Americana; and the director’s artistic relationship with blonde women has colored the film a million shades by a million viewers. It was not until I had watched some of Vertigo’s descendants, notably David Lynch’s Mulholland Drive that I felt the impact for which I had longed upon re-watching the film this summer.

Hitchcock’s cinematographic style change with each movie he makes, unlike the storybook qualities of Wes Anderson or the placid “Drops dripped.” of Andrei Tarkovsky. In Vertigo, he leads us into James Stewart’s distorted mind, a world shattered by the traumatic death of his police force–partner, by constricting our range of movement and mocking our spatial judgment. The partner falls from a San Francisco tenement while trying to save James Stewart, and suddenly, like Kim Novak’s character in double, Stewart’s steps into another’s life. This life is more traumatically metaphorical and very much less literal than that of Kim Novak’s character, but another life nonetheless. The fall and the height and the guilt confuse themselves in Stewart’s head to deliver him a crippling case of Vertigo, forcing him from the force for good.

Stewart’s friend exacerbates this confusion by sending him to surveil the friend’s wife, Novak’s original character. Such a clandestine project leads Stewart through the winding streets and seemingly circular history of San Francisco, where his friend’s wife has taken to emulating a crazed ancestor’s appearance. At this point, Hitchcock begins to insert spiral patterns everywhere. This pattern symbolizes the deepening plot, deepening conspiracy1, and deepening psychotic hole that Stewart finds his character in. The symbolism is patent, however, contrasting with other imagery employed by the director (imagery which would find amplification in what Lynch described as “dream logic”).

Alfred Hitchcock’s cinematographical trickery encloses James Stewart’s all-American character, disclosing the craze lurking inside his obsessed mind. With deep focus and a 2-D plane, cameras make the near and far appear unified. The video below2 demonstrates this several times. The whole video is a smörgåsbord of labyrinths, San Francisco history, and voyeurism, but turn the clock to 1:59 to see the images I can’t remove from my head.

Those yellow flowers that James Stewart walks behind appear taller than him in that moment, and the obscured view traps his figure in the history, mystery, and death that linger after Novak exits the scene. Hitchcock further unsettles viewers in :17, not with the normal technique of a dolly following Stewart and suggesting danger, but by a shot from below. This camera setting exaggerates the heights and lengths of objects outside focal point, making the 3ft flowers equal the 6ft Stewart in height. But the mastery here is the unresolved tension between these instances of camera trickery and Hitchcock’s usage of truly large objects. The enormity of the Golden Gate bridge in one famous shot anchors the nearly surreal imagery elsewhere in Vertigo, cementing a permanent unease throughout.

  1. Remember Hitchcock overlaps with noir films, from which he pulls much of his plot devices and motifs. ^
  2. Massive apologies for the aspect ratio, look for higher quality clips to see how wide the film really looks. ^

item.title: Open Data Package
item.description: As detailed here, I have found myself needing to write an API for the Federal Register, an otherwise wonderful site. As I began writing, I found another gap—Esri webmaps—and so forth. This, I hear, is how packages come to be. So it is with mine.

item.title: Meta
item.description:
Style

After nearly a decade of editing and publishing, I have become very particular about style even for myself. Of course, all the current style guides suck except Chicago, and Chicago still isn’t perfect. This site, however, is. I follow conventions of Chicago (excepting citations, which are technically difficult), but give precedence to the following rules:

  • Paragraphs demand proper spacing, not indentation
  • Braces, unless in mathematical notation, denote metasyntactical variables. Common metasyntactical variables, such as ‘John Doe’ or ‘foobar’, depend on the country or discipline of origin
  • When quoting, use “{quotation}”
  • When referring to a term for its definition or linguistic/literary characteristics, use ‘{term}’
  • Punctuation sits outside of both single and double quotation marks, unless it also occurs within such quotations
  • When employing free indirect discourse it is appropriate to include a question mark without ending a sentence
  • The Oxford comma creates ambiguities while clearing up none; it is disallowed
  • Unless conflicting with the formatting of the <> quotation, notes within quotations should only occur as such: “[{note}]“
  • Instead of double quotation marks, rarely used brackets in English (though often implemented in HTML), <<>>, denote terms that should be taken in another context, displacing quotation marks denoting distrust, sarcasm, or the inadequacy of language to convey full meanings

This blog was published on Hugo with Blogdown for R. All three are fantastic.

item.title: Federal Register API
item.description:
TL;DR

I created an R client to fetch data from the Federal Register, replacing an R package that had not been updated for years. It was my first foray into APIs.

Overview

The United States Federal Register is the [slowly] clearing house for every revision to US administrative law, regulatory enforcement, and the more stupid forms of jockeying and horn-tooting by federal agencies. The website, charged with the supremely bureaucratic duty of pigeonholing and circumscribing every sort of <> in Washington, is quite beautiful. Its ease, features, and appearance bear the marks of something that is truly for the public.

To aid readers, [and the odd corporation trying to stay a step ahead of environmental regulations,] the Office of the Federal Register got a leg up from a developer who made an API client for R. Unfortunately,1 that client has been rendered useless by updates. In the name of openness digital and governmental, I set to work on a new API client that would:

  1. work
  2. teach me the fundamentals of APIs
  3. display some clever solutions
  1. And quite ironically for an institution with steeped in such bureaucracy. ^
